metadata.name: Comstractions #71
metadata.description: This collection explores the combination of abstract shapes and comic book styles. Several vintage comic palettes and bold outlines breathe life into abstract superheroes and villains, animals and buildings.

metadata.name: Blind Gallery Club Membership #155
metadata.description:
The Blind Gallery Club is an art community that focuses on digital and generative art. 

Besides accessing the community, members get early access and discounts to the Blind Gallery events and special ways to experience the blind concept. 

Learn more: https://www.blindgallery.xyz/club

---
Generative art by Mark Knol (@mknol)

metadata.name: xyzrgb #135
metadata.description: a study on color interaction and form

metadata.name: Liminal Slippage #37
metadata.description:
Is this a metaphor of thoughts and perceptions slipping in and out the threshold of the mind? Or colours and shapes bleeding into a virtual focus, gaining grain in the process?

At least we know it's two passes through two different GLSL shaders, where simplex noise is computed and reinterpreted in multiple ways.

Press [spacebar] to toggle play/pause.

When paused, press [p] to create hi-res PNG.

metadata.name: th√©ba√Øde #34
metadata.description:
‚ÄúTh√©ba√Øde‚Äù is a french word for wild place, remote and peaceful, where to live in a calm retreat. It's also simply a desert and a synonym of solitude. It comes from Thebaid, an arid region of ancient Egypt and Thebes was the capital.

‚Äúth√©ba√Øde‚Äù is my debut on fx(hash), almost one year since my first works minted on Objkt (a series of Indian ink drawings, in January 2022). After learning the basics of creative coding recently, and a few works with this technique, I decided to create a first generative project. With "th√©ba√Øde" I chose to express the minimalist and narrative aspects of my artistic approach (though the title and concept emerged at the end). Gradually the work was resonating with philosophical matters I'm obsessed with since years: time, emptiness, human condition, erosion, desire, chance, combining them into a visual metaphor. The view of a vast area, a changing silhouette, an impenetrable monolith or an opening to elsewhere or nothing, day and night and day and night and dawn and dusk ‚Äî few elements able to compose a meditative and lasting tableau of questions and feelings.

Press ‚Äús‚Äù in live mode to save the work.
Made with p5js | 2023
Png |¬†2000 px x 2000 px | 72 ppi

www.antoniowerli.com

metadata.name: Topoexgrafia #5
metadata.description:
Personal genart of imaginary distant worlds, in topographical representation made by alien beings.
Ever since I was studying as a surveyor, I loved maps, that precision in taking measurements and scaling a portion of our planet on a sheet, made me understand how vast the earth was and how much the horizon deceived the eye .
After all, I also consider maps to be artistic expressions.
The code is unbundled, I've always shared everything I know, in the end the final result counts.

Let it grow.
Press S for transparent png.

objkt.name: O B S C V R V M #32

metadata.name: O B S C V R V M #32
metadata.description:
‚ÄúFelix, qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas‚Äù
Virgil, from Georgica, 29 BCE

The miracle of the appropriateness of the language of mathematics for the formulation of the laws of physics is a wonderful gift which we neither understand nor deserve. OBSCVRVM, meaning ‚Äúdarkness‚Äù in Latin, takes this profound insight from physicist Eugene Wigner and explores it through a series of code generated spatial compositions. This collection redefines basic concepts of distance and time, with elements in the scene seemingly evolving at different spatial and temporal scales. Its universe exists on the ambiguous boundary between the cosmic and subatomic, forgoing color in place of structure, articulated through a single light source and myriad of shadows it casts on the intricate lattice geometries.

Every token is a spatial composition consisting of a frame, a central lattice and a background, layered in space like theater scenography. Many frames are narrow and take a form of a portal, some take up the whole space in between, and some are missing altogether. Background features a star field with celestial objects like stars, planets, moons, eclipses and comets. The universe of OBSCVRVM is highly ordered, with lattice-like structures imprinted in star fields that span thousands of light years. You might find shattered lattices close to ancient celestial objects like meteor fields, novas, quasars and space-time raptures. In this universe time flows unevenly, and it might take eons for destructive forces to completely disintegrate the lattice and take it to its ultimate state ‚Äì heath death. Lattices themselves are formed through iterative subdivision rules from basic Platonic primitives. Special types of derived primitives called stations also appear, their origin still a mystery. Occasionally, a central lattice is missing from the composition, leaving the portal to frame a seemingly empty region of space. With over 250 calls to a random function within the code, the number of spatial configurations this generative system can produce is astoundingly large, although the collection explores only a small subset of them. 

Virgil‚Äôs quote from the beginning translates to: ‚ÄúFortunate them, who were able to know the causes of things‚Äù. We know little about the origin of these lattices, but through their intricate geometries, OBSCVRVM takes you on a journey to explore deep space and time and ponder over our own place in them.

LLP üññ

__________

OBSCVRVM collection is written in JavaScript using THREE.js library for displaying instantiated 3D geometry. Generation of lattices is done using our own, open-source mesh subdivision module, which includes a custom mesh class. 

Key controls:

a : jump light angle
f : cycle light framerate
t : cycle light tick
i : info
g : start / stop gif capture
b : white / black background
1 ‚Äì 5 : image capture 1-5x resolution 

Token looks best in live mode and 100% browser zoom. Change pixel density by changing your browser's zoom level (50% zoom doubles the pixels etc.) Tested on multiple browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge), devices (desktop, mobile) and operating systems (Windows, iOS). For best viewing experience, we recommend Chrome on desktop with a newer generation GPU card and enabled hardware acceleration. Due to recursive nature of geometry generation, some tokens might take much more time to generate. Please make sure the token works on your device before minting.

We were greatly inspired by Jacek Markusiewicz‚Äôs ‚Äúadrift‚Äù, lunarean's ‚ÄúHeat Death‚Äù, and Monotau‚Äôs ‚ÄúCradle‚Äù collections on fxhash, both by their approach to code as well as aesthetic synthesis of elements of their work. They motivated us to leave our code open (unminified and unobfuscated), available on public repositories (GitHub), and well documented through writing and talks so they can serve as inspiration to others. We see our support for open generative tools as a mission every generative artist should partake in. 

Created in 2022 by {protocell:labs}. You can find us on Twitter - @LukaPiskorec @00000Kane00000

issuer.name: O B S C V R V M

metadata.name: First Dance #260
metadata.description:
As imperfect and exciting as your first dance.

This project is meant to be a casual/fun minting experience to show appreciation to those that supported any of my projects in 2022. Thank you all.

Each output is generated from code written in p5js.

Created by Eric Davidson. 2023.

attributes.name: Palette
attributes.value: The careful cracking of the expanse

issuer.name: O B S C V R V M

metadata.name: Vents #142
metadata.description:
Near the start of December @Studio Yorktown launched his "Studio Yorktown Color Town Hall" library of wonderful colour palettes.

"You know what this Town Hall needs?" I asked no one in particular, "Vents!". Besides, what's more Christmassy than a good old vent?

Some nice soothing gradients, with a selection of innies and outies, structure, form, and sometimes sharp edges. I humbly suggest aiming to get a set of three üòÅ

Thank you for everything fxhash in 2022, looking forwards to 2023!

READ MORE: https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/vents

INSTRUCTIONS ::

h - Toggle high-res
n - toggle noise on/off
s - Download and save image

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS ::

High-res will output a 8,192 x 8,192 image, at 300dpi it should print at...

27.3 x 27.3 inches
69.3 x 69.3 cm

attributes.name: Vent Layout
attributes.value: All Out Everywhere All At Once

metadata.name: Tangentum #4
metadata.description:
We live in a multiverse: an infinite-dimensional space of variants. Everything exists here. Everything is possible. Each subset of a multiverse has its own unique laws of physics, a set of rules, and its own distinct features.

Tangentum creates a projection of a random multiverse subset to a 2-dimensional plane. Each variation is a unique representation of the force field, that exists somewhere at some point in time.

This work starts a series of my visual exploration of functions, continuity, and boundedness, and I would love to share it with you.


Please use fullscreen or download artwork in high resolution for a better viewing experience.

Tested with Chrome 107, Safari, and Firefox. Chrome is recommended, other browsers are slower on this artwork.

Saving with high and ultra-high resolution may take a while, please be patient.


Made with love and p5js


Controls in fullscreen:
[1] - save PNG 2700 x 1800
[2] - save PNG 5400 x 3800
[3] - save PNG 10800 x 7600
[4] - save PNG 16200 x 11400

metadata.name: Hyper Pixel #30
metadata.description:
Somewhere between pixel-art and axonometric architectural projections, spatial compositions assembled from multi-resolution pixel precise fragments. 

Hyper Pixel is the result of a continued interest in using projections to represent three dimensional object in  two dimensional picture image, and embracing the fact that all digital images are two dimensional arrays of discrete pixels. In that sense it is also a reaction against both skeuomorphism, or mimicking older media in digital form, and the push towards ever increasing fidelity and resolution. The project uses Military perspective, a form of oblique projection, or 45¬∞ - 45¬∞ axonometric projection, because these angels can approximated fittingly by square pixel grid. 

Press s, m, l, x for exporting an image with increasing resolution.
Press p for pause.
Press r for refresh.

Made with P5.js by @introspect0r

metadata.name: Ordinary Places #197
metadata.description:
‚ÄúOrdinary Places‚Äù is a fully-coded meditation on the poetic beauty of everyday landscapes. 

The architectural characters in these landscapes include water towers (inspired by Bernd & Hilla Becher‚Äôs ‚ÄúWater Tower‚Äù photography series), gas stations (inspired by Ed Ruscha‚Äôs ‚Äú26 Gasoline Stations‚Äù photography book), and barns (inspired by childhood memories on my grandfather‚Äôs farm). 

Yet, while these scenes may seem ordinary upon first glance, something darker lurks beneath the surface. The hidden secrets of these Ordinary Places can only be revealed through the minting process. In this sense, the outputs are not merely a collection individual scenes, but instead, a coherent world animated by shared themes and narratives.     

Pressing the down arrow saves the coded output as a .png image.
